Robert Gottlieb, who otherwise found much to admire in John Steinbeck, argued that he was politically _________, offering an adolescent disaffection in place of settled judgment.
A.	naïve
B.	perspicacious
C.	contemptible
D.	keen
E.	callow
F.	disinterested
